ContinuityNotes: Continues DS9’s long-running exploration of the Mirror Universe.
Features Mirror versions of Ezri and Worf for the first time.
Serves as a lighter, caper-style episode amid the darker final-season war arc.
ThematicNotes: Greed, loyalty, and self-preservation in extreme circumstances.
How familiar faces can take radically different paths in alternate realities.
The danger of destabilizing technology in a volatile political landscape.
BehindTheScenes: One of DS9’s last Mirror Universe outings, leaning heavily into comedy and adventure.
Allows regular cast members to play exaggerated or inverted versions of their characters.
Combines Ferengi-centric humor with Mirror Universe swashbuckling.

Title: Field of Fire
Summary:
When a young Starfleet officer named Ilario is found murdered in his quarters with a seemingly impossible long-range head shot, DS9 is shaken by the presence of a killer in its midst. Sisko assigns Ezri Dax to assist in the investigation, hoping her training in counseling and her access to the memories of past hosts might provide insight into the murderer’s psychology. Ezri reluctantly calls upon the persona of Joran Dax, a previous host who was a latent psychopath and killer, locked away in the symbiont’s suppressed memories.

Working with Bashir and station security, Ezri and the internal vision of Joran reconstruct the crime, discovering that the weapon is a rare TR-116 rifle modified with a micro-transporter and sensor system, allowing the shooter to kill through bulkheads from a remote location. The investigation reveals that the killer is Chu’lak, a Vulcan officer whose experiences in the Dominion War have shattered his logical detachment, unleashing a cold, methodical murderous rage. In a tense confrontation, Ezri uses the sniper rifle herself to outmaneuver and disarm Chu’lak before he can claim another victim, rejecting Joran’s seductive encouragement to enjoy the kill. She emerges shaken but more resolved to accept and control the darker aspects of the Dax legacy.

StorySections.Text: A Starfleet officer is found dead in his quarters, apparently shot at point-blank range despite all doors and sensors being intact.
Ezri is assigned to profile the killer and reluctantly turns to the buried memories of Joran Dax for insight into a murderer’s mind.
Joran’s presence in Ezri’s thoughts unnerves her as they deduce that the weapon must be capable of firing through walls from a hidden vantage point.
Bashir and Ezri identify the TR-116 rifle with micro-transporter modifications as the murder weapon, narrowing the suspect pool to a traumatized Vulcan, Chu’lak.
Using the same weapon and Joran’s knowledge, Ezri corners Chu’lak. She stops him without giving in to Joran’s urge to relish the kill.
Ezri symbolically dismisses Joran, acknowledging his presence but asserting her own control over Dax’s darker legacy.

EntitySummaries.Ezri Dax: Ezri Dax is DS9’s counselor, forced to harness the memories of a murderous past host to stop a present-day serial killer.
EntitySummaries.Benjamin Sisko: Benjamin Sisko is DS9’s commander, who trusts Ezri with the difficult task of hunting a killer using the Dax symbiont’s troubled past.
EntitySummaries.Julian Bashir: Julian Bashir is DS9’s doctor and Ezri’s ally, helping analyze evidence and the specialized weapon used in the murders.
EntitySummaries.Joran Dax: Joran Dax is a former host of the Dax symbiont, a brilliant but psychopathic musician whose murderous impulses haunt Ezri’s investigation.
EntitySummaries.Chu'lak: Chu’lak is a Vulcan officer whose war trauma has twisted his logic into cold-blooded vengeance, turning him into a sniper who kills fellow officers.
EntitySummaries.Ilario: Ilario is a cheerful young Starfleet officer whose seemingly senseless murder sparks the investigation.
EntitySummaries.Chu'lak, the sniper: Chu’lak, the sniper, embodies the breakdown of Vulcan discipline under the psychological strain of war.
EntitySummaries.Joran Dax's murderous impulses: Joran Dax’s murderous impulses are the dark corner of Dax’s past that Ezri must acknowledge without succumbing to.

ContinuityNotes: Further explores the suppressed memories of Joran Dax introduced in "Equilibrium" and revisited in later Trill storylines.
Showcases the psychological impact of the Dominion War on even the most disciplined officers.
Strengthens Ezri’s arc as she reconciles the many lives and flaws within the Dax symbiont.
ThematicNotes: Confronting the darkness within oneself without letting it define you.
The toll of war on mental stability and moral restraint.
The ethics of using dangerous knowledge and tools for a greater good.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a murder-mystery thriller centered on Ezri Dax.
Features a rare and memorable weapon concept in the TR-116 sniper rifle.
Gives Nicole de Boer and the portrayal of Joran substantial psychological material.

Title: Chimera
Summary:
While returning to DS9, Odo and Kira encounter a mysterious shapeshifter whose ship is disabled. Introducing himself as Laas, he reveals that he is one of the hundred infant Changelings sent out by the Founders long ago to explore the galaxy—just like Odo. Unlike Odo, Laas has spent centuries among solids and has grown deeply contemptuous of them, seeing non-shapeshifters as fearful, limited beings who can never truly accept his kind.

On DS9, Laas encourages Odo to embrace his Changeling nature more fully, reveling in extended, expressive shapeshifting and urging him to abandon solids altogether. Tensions flare when Laas is provoked by local Klingons and responds by defending himself in a way that leads to a fatality, landing him in custody. Kira struggles with jealousy and fear that Odo might leave with Laas to seek a life among their own kind. Ultimately, Odo chooses Kira and the community they have built on DS9, using his abilities to help Laas escape prosecution. Laas departs to continue searching for other Changelings, while Odo accepts that his identity is shaped as much by his love for Kira as by his nature as a Changeling.

StorySections.Text: Odo and Kira rescue a stranded shapeshifter, who reveals himself to be one of the hundred Changelings sent out by the Founders.
Laas arrives on DS9, criticizing solids and urging Odo to explore his abilities and true nature without restraint.
Extended changeling flights with Laas thrill Odo but worry Kira, who senses Laas undermining Odo’s ties to the station.
A confrontation with hostile Klingons leads to Laas killing one in self-defense, inflaming tensions and resulting in his arrest.
Faced with Laas’s likely conviction, Odo secretly helps him escape, but chooses to remain on DS9 with Kira instead of leaving with him.
Laas departs to search for other Changelings, while Odo and Kira reaffirm their bond, aware of the choices that shaped their lives.

EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo is DS9’s Changeling security chief, torn between solidarity with his own kind and his love and loyalty to Kira and the station.
EntitySummaries.Kira Nerys: Kira Nerys is DS9’s Bajoran commander, who fears losing Odo but ultimately supports the choice that affirms their relationship.
EntitySummaries.Laas: Laas is a member of the hundred Changelings, embittered by centuries of prejudice and convinced that solids can never truly accept his people.
EntitySummaries.Quark: Quark observes the mounting tensions and provides a pragmatic perspective on how others view Changelings.
EntitySummaries.Alpha Quadrant prejudice against Changel: Alpha Quadrant prejudice against Changelings is embodied in suspicion, fear, and quickness to see them as threats.

Title: Badda-Bing, Badda-Bang
Antagonists: Frankie Eyes and his mob takeover
Racism and corruption of 1960s Las Vegas
Summary:
A sudden program alteration in the holosuite transforms Vic Fontaine’s beloved 1960s Las Vegas lounge simulation: mobster Frankie Eyes shows up with orders from the unseen Mr. Clarke, seizing control of Vic’s casino and turning it into a crooked operation. If the crew does nothing, the new parameters mean Vic will eventually be forced out and the lounge erased. Treating the situation as real as any mission, the DS9 crew decides to plan an elaborate heist—Ocean’s Eleven style—to get Frankie out and restore Vic’s control.

Sisko initially refuses to participate, uncomfortable with celebrating an era and setting that historically excluded people like him and Kasidy. After a heartfelt conversation with Kasidy about reclaiming the fantasy on their own terms, he joins the scheme. The crew rehearses a complex plan involving rigged casino tables, power cuts, and synchronized distractions. On the night of the heist, there are near-misses and improvisations, but they ultimately trick Frankie, steal the money he owes his boss, and force his removal from the program. Vic regains his lounge, the crew revels in their victory, and for one night, the burdens of the war are held at bay by music, friendship, and a caper well pulled off.

StorySections.Text: The crew enters Vic Fontaine’s lounge to find a new mobster, Frankie Eyes, taking over the casino under orders from a powerful boss.
Vic explains that the altered program will eventually erase him if nothing changes. The crew resolves to help him beat the mob at their own game.
While most of the crew enthusiastically plans the heist, Sisko refuses to join, citing the real-world racism of 1960s Las Vegas.
Kasidy persuades Sisko that they can rewrite the fantasy to include themselves. Sisko joins the caper, and the team rehearses every step.
During the real operation, glitches force improvisation, but the crew pulls off the robbery, exposes Frankie, and ensures his removal from the program.
Vic’s lounge is restored, and the crew celebrates together, savoring a rare moment of joy amid the Dominion War.

Title: Inter Arma Enim Silent Leges
Summary:
Bashir is invited to attend a medical conference on Romulus as part of a diplomatic goodwill mission, but his trip takes a darker turn when he is contacted by Luther Sloan of Section 31. Sloan claims to need Bashir’s observational skills to assess whether Koval, head of the Romulan Tal Shiar, secretly suffers from a degenerative disease—information that could destabilize Romulan politics. Bashir, mistrustful of Section 31’s methods, agrees only reluctantly and insists that Starfleet Intelligence be informed.

On Romulus, Bashir finds himself entangled in a web of deceit involving Senator Cretak, Koval, Sloan, and even Admiral Ross. What begins as a simple diagnostic mission becomes a covert operation to ensure that an anti-Federation Romulan faction does not gain power. In the end, Bashir realizes that Sloan’s apparent capture and interrogation were staged, and that Ross has been complicit with Section 31 all along to manipulate Romulan leadership. Although the Federation’s strategic position is strengthened, Bashir is left deeply disturbed by the motto that "in times of war, the law falls silent," questioning what the Federation is becoming in the name of victory.

Title: Penumbra
Antagonists: Breens' growing role in the war
Summary:
When Worf’s ship goes missing in a battle against the Dominion, Ezri Dax becomes increasingly worried and decides to search for him on her own, commandeering a runabout despite Sisko’s orders to wait. Her search leads her deep into hostile space, where she eventually finds Worf alive but stranded after a battle with the Breen. Their forced proximity and shared history reignite complicated feelings between them even as they argue about duty, love, and the legacy of Jadzia.

Back on DS9, Sisko finally proposes to Kasidy Yates, who joyfully accepts. However, his happiness is clouded when the Prophets appear in a vision and warn him that if he marries Kasidy, he will know nothing but sorrow. Struggling to reconcile his roles as captain, Emissary, and husband-to-be, Sisko temporarily calls off the wedding. Meanwhile, on Bajor, Dukat—disguised surgically as a Bajoran—arrives and insinuates himself into Kai Winn’s life as "Anjohl Tennan," claiming to be guided by the Prophets. Winn, recently cut off from the Prophets’ guidance, is vulnerable to his flattery and begins to see him as a spiritual advisor, unknowingly inviting a servant of the Pah-wraiths into Bajor’s highest religious office.

Title: 'Til Death Do Us Part
Summary:
Haunted by the Prophets’ warning that marriage to Kasidy will bring only sorrow, Sisko breaks off their engagement, leaving Kasidy hurt and angry. After counsel from his father and a deeper reflection on his own desires, Sisko chooses love and free will over fear, reconciling with Kasidy and going through with the wedding in a ceremony performed by Admiral Ross on DS9. Even as they wed, the shadow of the Prophets’ warning lingers over their future.

Meanwhile, Worf and Ezri remain prisoners of the Breen and Dominion, their captivity forcing them to confront their complicated feelings. Under duress, they confess love for one another, only to later realize that their bond is more about grief and confusion than a lasting romantic connection. In another thread, Dukat, still disguised as Anjohl, manipulates Kai Winn by claiming that the Prophets have turned away from her and that Bajor’s true destiny lies with the Pah-wraiths. The Female Changeling and Weyoun, recognizing the Breen’s value as allies, move toward a formal alliance, while Damar grows increasingly uneasy with the Dominion’s domination of Cardassia and the cost of their partnership.

Title: Strange Bedfellows
Summary:
The Dominion cements its alliance with the Breen, granting them increasing power and access while Cardassia is pushed further into the role of expendable junior partner. Damar watches in growing disgust as the Female Changeling and Weyoun treat his people’s sacrifices as disposable, forcing him to confront the realization that Cardassia has become little more than a Dominion pawn. His private resentment begins to coalesce into thoughts of rebellion.

Meanwhile, Worf and Ezri are condemned to execution by the Dominion but find unexpected salvation when Damar, finally pushed past his breaking point, murders Weyoun’s latest clone and helps them escape. This act marks Damar’s transformation from collaborator to resistance leader. On Bajor, Kai Winn fully embraces Dukat’s guidance, rejecting the Prophets and beginning to study forbidden Pah-wraith texts. Sisko, newly married, continues to feel the lurking unease of the Prophets’ warning as the war’s stakes and the spiritual battle for Bajor both intensify.

Title: The Changing Face of Evil
Summary:
The Dominion War reaches a new level of devastation when the Breen launch a surprise assault on Starfleet Headquarters in San Francisco, crippling the Federation’s defenses and signaling that nowhere is truly safe. In the aftermath, the Defiant joins a counteroffensive, only to be destroyed in battle, leaving Sisko and his crew shaken by the loss of their ship and the mounting evidence that the war may be turning decisively against them.

On Cardassia, Damar openly declares rebellion against the Dominion, broadcasting a message to his people calling for resistance and striking a major blow by destroying a Vorta cloning facility. His actions inspire hope across the Alpha Quadrant but invite brutal reprisals from the Dominion, which clamps down on Cardassia even more harshly. Meanwhile on Bajor, Kai Winn, having fully embraced the Pah-wraiths, reads the forbidden Book of the Kosst Amojan under Dukat’s guidance. When Solbor, her loyal aide, discovers Dukat’s true identity and the nature of her new faith, Winn murders him to protect her path, sealing her fall from grace. As the war and spiritual conflicts escalate, Sisko, now without the Defiant, prepares for the next phase of a fight that has become both physical and metaphysical.

Sisko mourns the Defiant but receives word of a new ship on the way, while Damar’s rebellion and Winn’s descent reshape the war’s stakes.

Title: When It Rains...
Summary:
With the Cardassian resistance struggling, Starfleet assigns Kira Nerys—now wearing a Starfleet uniform—along with Garak and Odo to train Damar’s rebels in guerrilla tactics. Their arrival on the Cardassian base is met with deep suspicion, especially from hard-liner Legate Rusot, who resents taking lessons from a former Bajoran resistance fighter. While Kira pushes Damar to accept sabotage and hit‑and‑run strikes, Odo hides the fact that he is suffering from the same degenerative disease afflicting the Founders, his condition worsening after each shapeshift.

On DS9, Bashir and Ezri discover that Odo’s symptoms match those of the Great Link, and Bashir begins to suspect that the morphogenic virus was deliberately engineered. Meanwhile, in the Klingon Empire, Gowron assumes direct control of the war effort, sidelining Martok and ordering suicidal attacks to bolster his own glory at the expense of battlefield effectiveness. On Bajor, Kai Winn continues to feel abandoned by the Prophets and turns more fully to the teachings of the Pah‑wraiths under the guidance of the disguised Dukat, setting Bajor on a dangerous spiritual course even as the Alpha Quadrant faces military catastrophe.

Title: Tacking into the Wind
Summary:
As the Dominion–Breen alliance gains ground, Kira leads Damar’s resistance cell on a dangerous mission to steal a Breen energy dampening weapon from a Dominion shipyard. Tensions boil over when Legate Rusot proposes killing Kira once the mission is complete, unable to stomach taking orders from a Bajoran. Damar, forced to choose between old prejudices and the future of Cardassia, ultimately kills Rusot and affirms that Cardassia must change if its rebellion is to mean anything.

Meanwhile, Odo’s illness has progressed so far that he can barely hold his shape, yet he insists on joining the mission, refusing to be left behind. Aboard the allied flagship, Worf and Martok watch in horror as Gowron continues to order reckless assaults designed to discredit Martok and secure his own legacy, squandering ships and warriors. Worf finally challenges Gowron in single combat and kills him, then refuses the Chancellorship, instead insisting that Martok take the role. With the Klingon leadership stabilized and the rebels now armed with knowledge of the Breen weapon, the allies gain new hope even as Odo’s condition worsens.

StorySections.Text: The Breen weapon continues to cripple allied ships, while Kira and Damar plan a high‑risk raid to even the odds.
Kira, Garak, Damar, Odo, and Rusot infiltrate a Dominion facility to steal data on the Breen energy dampening device.
Odo struggles with his failing health during the mission, and Rusot’s simmering hatred of Kira edges toward mutiny.
Back with the Klingon fleet, Gowron orders another disastrous assault, prompting Martok and Worf to question his sanity and motives.
Damar kills Rusot to prevent Kira’s murder and commits to a new Cardassia, while Worf challenges and kills Gowron, naming Martok the new Chancellor.
Armed with intelligence on the Breen weapon and a revitalized Klingon command, the allies prepare for the next phase of the war even as Odo deteriorates.

EntitySummaries.Kira Nerys: Kira Nerys leads the Cardassian resistance strike team, forcing Damar to confront the prejudices that helped create Cardassia’s downfall.
EntitySummaries.Damar: Damar fully embraces his role as revolutionary leader when he chooses a new future for Cardassia over loyalty to bigots like Rusot.
EntitySummaries.Elim Garak: Elim Garak aids the infiltration and sees in Damar’s choice a glimmer of hope for a better Cardassia.
EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo insists on fighting despite his terminal illness, embodying the personal cost of the war and the virus.
EntitySummaries.Worf: Worf challenges Gowron’s corruption, kills him in honorable combat, and reshapes the Empire by elevating Martok.
EntitySummaries.Martok: Martok becomes Chancellor of the Klingon Empire, bringing hard‑won battlefield experience and humility to the position.
EntitySummaries.Gowron: Gowron’s political scheming and reckless tactics finally doom his rule and nearly the war effort before Worf stops him.
EntitySummaries.Legate Rusot: Legate Rusot is a reactionary Cardassian officer whose refusal to change leads to his death at Damar’s hand.
EntitySummaries.Dominion and Breen military advantage: The Dominion and Breen military advantage, centered on the energy dampening weapon, threatens to crush the alliance before the rebels’ intervention.

ContinuityNotes: Resolves long‑running questions about Gowron’s leadership by installing Martok as Chancellor.
Pushes Damar from reluctant rebel to true revolutionary hero.
Provides the allies with crucial information on countering the Breen weapon.
ThematicNotes: Leadership as service versus leadership as self‑aggrandizement.
The necessity of change for societies seeking redemption.
Personal sacrifice in the face of terminal illness and war.
BehindTheScenes: A pivotal episode in DS9’s endgame, paying off Klingon and Cardassian political arcs.
Features a major honorary duel between Worf and Gowron, a key franchise figure.
Balances infiltration thriller elements with high‑stakes political drama.

Title: Extreme Measures
Summary:
Desperate to save Odo and the Founders from the morphogenic virus, Bashir and O’Brien concoct a plan to lure Section 31 to DS9 by faking evidence that they have discovered a cure. Their bait works when Luther Sloan appears, but he attempts suicide rather than allow Federation secrets to be exposed. To salvage any hope, Bashir and O’Brien use an experimental neural link to enter Sloan’s dying mind, navigating a shifting landscape of memories, deceptions, and psychological defenses.

Inside Sloan’s subconscious, they encounter seemingly benign domestic scenes, Starfleet briefings, and false exits designed to trap them until Sloan dies, taking the cure with him. O’Brien plays the skeptic and pragmatist, pushing Bashir to ignore distractions and prioritize the mission over moral qualms about rummaging through Sloan’s private thoughts. In the end, Bashir locates the data on the virus and its cure among Sloan’s deepest secrets, escaping Sloan’s collapsing mind with the information just in time. Sloan dies, but Bashir returns with the knowledge needed to save Odo and potentially end a genocidal plan carried out in the Federation’s name.

StorySections.Text: Bashir and O’Brien scheme to lure Section 31 to DS9 by broadcasting fake progress on a cure for the Changeling virus.
Luther Sloan arrives and attempts suicide rather than be interrogated, forcing Bashir to consider a risky neural incursion into Sloan’s mind.
Inside Sloan’s subconscious, Bashir and O’Brien navigate false realities and decoys meant to protect Section 31’s secrets.
The two officers dig deeper, confronting Sloan’s justifications, guilt, and duplicity as his mind tries to bury the cure forever.
Bashir locates and memorizes the data on the virus and its cure just as Sloan’s mental world collapses, and he and O’Brien barely escape.
Back in the infirmary, Sloan dies, but Bashir now holds the key to saving Odo and ending Section 31’s genocidal plan.

EntitySummaries.Julian Bashir: Julian Bashir is DS9’s doctor, who violates his own ethical comfort zone by invading Sloan’s mind to obtain the cure for Odo’s illness.
EntitySummaries.Miles O'Brien: Miles O’Brien is DS9’s chief engineer and Bashir’s closest friend, acting as the grounded, strategic partner inside Sloan’s subconscious.
EntitySummaries.Luther Sloan: Luther Sloan is a Section 31 operative whose dying mind becomes the battleground for the Federation’s moral soul and the Changelings’ survival.
EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo’s worsening condition drives Bashir and O’Brien to take unprecedented risks to obtain the cure.
EntitySummaries.Section 31's secrecy: Section 31’s secrecy manifests in layers of mental defenses and moral rationalizations inside Sloan’s mind.
EntitySummaries.Morphogenic virus killing the Founders: The morphogenic virus killing the Founders is a clandestine Federation bioweapon whose cure Bashir wrests from Sloan’s subconscious.

ContinuityNotes: Directly continues the storyline of Odo’s illness and Section 31’s role in creating the Changeling virus.
Further exposes the extent and mindset of Section 31 within the Federation.
Provides the knowledge necessary for the eventual cure of the Founders.
ThematicNotes: The ethical limits of ends‑justify‑the‑means thinking in wartime.
Friendship and trust as anchors in surreal, high‑stakes circumstances.
The psychological cost of secret wars and clandestine organizations.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a mind‑bending psychological bottle episode centered on Bashir, O’Brien, and Sloan.
Uses dreamlike visuals and shifting realities to dramatize an information heist.
Deepens the franchise’s exploration of Section 31’s controversial methods.

Title: The Dogs of War
Summary:
The Cardassian resistance suffers a devastating setback when the Dominion destroys one of its key bases, forcing Damar, Kira, and Garak to operate from hiding among ordinary Cardassians. Rather than crushing the rebellion, the atrocity ignites popular anger, and Damar becomes a symbol of hope as whispers of resistance spread through Cardassian cities. The Female Changeling and Weyoun respond with brutal crackdowns, but it is clear that Cardassia is no longer firmly in Dominion hands. Odo, now armed with the cure from Bashir, begins to contemplate his responsibility to the Great Link as well as to Kira.

On DS9, Sisko is given command of a new Defiant‑class ship, the Sao Paulo, which Starfleet grants permission to rename Defiant, restoring a crucial symbol to the crew on the eve of the final offensive. Meanwhile, Ferengi politics collide with the war when Quark learns that Grand Nagus Zek plans to retire and name his successor. Expecting the job himself, Quark is stunned to discover that Zek’s reforms—spurred by Ishka—have transformed Ferengi society into a quasi‑social democracy, and that Rom, not Quark, will become Nagus. As Quark fumes over the end of “true” Ferengi values, Rom accepts the role, signaling a new era for Ferenginar while the Alpha Quadrant steels itself for a last, decisive campaign.

StorySections.Text: The Dominion wipes out a major Cardassian resistance base, and Sisko receives word of a new Defiant‑class warship.
Damar, Kira, and Garak hide among civilians, discovering that the Dominion’s brutality has sparked widespread anger on Cardassia.
The Female Changeling and Weyoun tighten their grip, but ordinary Cardassians begin to see Damar as the leader of a broader uprising.
On DS9, Quark learns that Zek is retiring and believes he will be the next Grand Nagus, only to find Ferengi culture has changed dramatically.
Zek names Rom as his successor, while Sisko assumes command of the Sao Paulo, renaming her Defiant as the allies plan a final offensive.
Damar prepares to call Cardassia to open rebellion, and the crew of the new Defiant readies itself for the war’s endgame.

EntitySummaries.Damar: Damar becomes a folk hero to ordinary Cardassians as the Dominion’s reprisals transform him into the face of resistance.
EntitySummaries.Elim Garak: Elim Garak operates from the shadows on Cardassia, coordinating underground efforts and observing his world’s potential rebirth.
EntitySummaries.Quark: Quark is a Ferengi bartender who expects to inherit the role of Grand Nagus, only to find himself out of step with Ferenginar’s new values.
EntitySummaries.Rom: Rom, Quark’s brother and a brilliant engineer, is unexpectedly named Grand Nagus and accepts the responsibility of reshaping Ferengi society.
EntitySummaries.Nog: Nog supports his father and uncle while continuing to serve in Starfleet aboard the Defiant.
EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo, now with the knowledge of a cure, wrestles with what he owes to the Founders and to Kira as the war nears its climax.
EntitySummaries.Female Changeling: The Female Changeling responds to rebellion with escalating violence even as her illness and desperation grow.
EntitySummaries.Weyoun: Weyoun represents Dominion authority on Cardassia, increasingly frantic as control slips away.
EntitySummaries.Grand Nagus Zek: Grand Nagus Zek is the aging Ferengi leader who, influenced by Ishka, has implemented sweeping social and economic reforms.
EntitySummaries.Ishka: Ishka, Quark and Rom’s mother, is the architect of Ferengi reform and Zek’s partner, pushing Ferenginar toward equality and regulation.
EntitySummaries.Brunt: Brunt, once a feared FCA liquidator, is marginalized by the new order and forced to accept Rom’s rise.
EntitySummaries.Dominion crackdown on Cardassia: The Dominion crackdown on Cardassia is a campaign of terror that backfires, galvanizing resistance instead of destroying it.
EntitySummaries.Ferengi traditionalists resisting reform: Ferengi traditionalists resisting reform, embodied by Quark, lament the end of unrestrained profit and exploitation.

ContinuityNotes: Sets the stage for Cardassia’s full‑scale uprising in the series finale.
Introduces the new Defiant‑class ship that will serve in the final battle.
Resolves the long‑running Ferengi political arc by naming Rom Grand Nagus and cementing Ferengi reforms.
ThematicNotes: How oppression can unify a people against their occupiers.
The tension between nostalgia for old orders and the necessity of reform.
Symbols of continuity, like the Defiant, as sources of morale in wartime.
BehindTheScenes: Acts as a penultimate setup episode, aligning political and personal pieces for the finale.
Blends war drama with Ferengi comedy to showcase DS9’s tonal range.
Provides closure for recurring Ferengi characters while escalating the Cardassian rebellion.

Title: What You Leave Behind, Part I
Summary:
The final offensive begins as a combined Federation, Klingon, and Romulan fleet launches into Cardassian space to confront the Dominion and Breen. Sisko, Ross, and Martok agree that the assault will mean enormous casualties but see no alternative if the Alpha Quadrant is to remain free. On Cardassia Prime, Damar, Kira, and Garak spearhead a coordinated uprising, sabotaging Dominion installations and inspiring city‑wide revolts. Outraged, the Female Changeling orders entire Cardassian cities destroyed, including Lakarian City, killing millions and pushing Cardassia to the brink of ruin.

The brutal reprisals only strengthen resistance, but also leave Damar scarred and enraged. As the battle in space rages, the ground campaign on Cardassia becomes more desperate. In parallel, Kai Winn and Dukat travel to the Fire Caves on Bajor with the Kosst Amojan, intent on releasing the Pah‑wraiths and sealing the Prophets away forever. Sisko, sensing that his role as Emissary is reaching its climax, prepares to face a destiny that may require the ultimate sacrifice even as the war approaches its decisive moment.

StorySections.Text: Sisko, Ross, and Martok agree to a final, massive assault on the Dominion, aware that victory will come at a staggering price.
The allied fleet heads into Cardassian space, while Damar, Kira, and Garak ignite open rebellion on Cardassia Prime.
Cardassian citizens join the uprising, prompting the enraged Female Changeling to order planetary reprisals that annihilate entire cities.
Damar and his team fight their way toward Dominion headquarters as news of Lakarian City’s destruction shocks even hardened Cardassians.
Kai Winn and Dukat enter the Fire Caves with the Book of the Kosst Amojan, beginning a ritual to unleash the Pah‑wraiths as Sisko feels an ominous pull from Bajor.
The battle and uprising intensify, with the outcome of the Dominion War and Bajor’s spiritual fate hanging in the balance.

EntitySummaries.Benjamin Sisko: Benjamin Sisko leads the allied fleet into the war’s final battle while sensing that his duties as Emissary are about to demand a personal sacrifice.
EntitySummaries.Kira Nerys: Kira Nerys fights alongside Damar and Garak on Cardassia, turning her experience as a former resistance fighter against a new occupier.
EntitySummaries.Damar: Damar leads Cardassia’s uprising, evolving from collaborator to martyr‑in‑waiting for his world’s freedom.
EntitySummaries.Elim Garak: Elim Garak accompanies Damar and Kira into the heart of Cardassia’s ruins, confronting the destruction of the world he once served.
EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo prepares for the possibility that he may have to return to the Great Link to end the war and cure his people.
EntitySummaries.Worf: Worf fights aboard the allied flagship, seeing the war through under Martok’s chancellorship.
EntitySummaries.Julian Bashir: Julian Bashir serves on the front lines, readying the cure for deployment if a chance to use it on the Founders arises.
EntitySummaries.Ezri Dax: Ezri Dax supports the crew during the final battle, her relationships with Worf and Bashir now clarified.
EntitySummaries.Female Changeling: The Female Changeling orders genocidal reprisals on Cardassia, her illness and rage pushing her toward total war.
EntitySummaries.Weyoun: Weyoun faithfully executes the Founders’ will, viewing Cardassian lives as expendable assets.
EntitySummaries.Kai Winn: Kai Winn enters the Fire Caves determined to claim power through the Pah‑wraiths after feeling rejected by the Prophets.
EntitySummaries.Dukat: Dukat accompanies Winn as a Pah‑wraith devotee, scheming to reshape the galaxy under their fiery dominion.
EntitySummaries.Admiral Ross: Admiral Ross shares overall command of the allied fleet, struggling with the necessary losses required for victory.
EntitySummaries.Martok: Martok, as Klingon Chancellor, revels in the glory of battle but also understands the cost of the final push.
EntitySummaries.Dominion rule on Cardassia: Dominion rule on Cardassia reaches its most brutal phase as mass reprisals attempt to crush the uprising.
EntitySummaries.Pah-wraith conspiracy on Bajor: The Pah‑wraith conspiracy on Bajor threatens to overturn the Prophets’ influence and unleash apocalyptic change.

ContinuityNotes: First half of DS9’s series finale, bringing the Dominion War and the Pah‑wraith arc to their climactic stages.
Shows the full scale of Cardassia’s uprising and the Dominion’s genocidal response.
Positions Sisko, Winn, and Dukat for their final confrontation in the Fire Caves.
ThematicNotes: The terrible costs of liberation and the scars left on a world after occupation.
The interplay between personal destiny and galactic‑scale conflict.
How fanaticism and fear can drive leaders to atrocities.
BehindTheScenes: Begins the two‑part series finale, intercutting large‑scale space battles with intimate character moments.
Uses extensive visual effects to depict the final Allied–Dominion confrontation.
Brings together long‑running plot threads involving Cardassia, the Dominion, and Bajoran religion.

Title: What You Leave Behind, Part II
Summary:
On Cardassia Prime, Damar, Kira, and Garak lead an assault on Dominion headquarters. Damar is killed in the fighting, but Kira and Garak push on, reaching the Female Changeling. Odo beams down, offers her the cure, and links with her, sharing both the virus’s remedy and his understanding of solids’ capacity for change. Moved by what she experiences through Odo, the Founder orders an immediate surrender, ending the Dominion War. Odo then chooses to return with her to the Great Link to cure his people and help guide them toward a less fearful existence, saying a bittersweet farewell to Kira.

In the Fire Caves, Kai Winn turns on Dukat at the last moment, attempting to stop the Pah‑wraiths, but is killed as Dukat becomes their vessel. Sisko arrives, battles Dukat with the Prophets’ aid, and ultimately casts both himself and Dukat into the chasm, sealing the Pah‑wraiths away but becoming a non‑linear being with the Prophets. In the aftermath, DS9’s crew begins to move on: O’Brien prepares to teach at Starfleet Academy, Worf becomes Federation ambassador to Qo’noS, Bashir and Ezri embark on a relationship, and Kira assumes command of the station. In a final montage, the friends say their quiet goodbyes as Kira and Jake look out at the wormhole, knowing Sisko still exists with the Prophets, waiting for a time when he may return.

StorySections.Text: Damar, Kira, and Garak continue their assault on Dominion headquarters as the allied fleets press the advantage in orbit.
Damar is killed in the fighting, but Kira and Garak break through Dominion lines and confront the entrenched leadership.
Odo beams to the surface, links with the Female Changeling, cures her, and convinces her to surrender, ending the war.
In the Fire Caves, Winn betrays Dukat but dies as he becomes the Pah‑wraiths’ vessel; Sisko arrives for their final confrontation.
Sisko and Dukat struggle as avatars of Prophets and Pah‑wraiths until Sisko casts them both into the flames, sealing the Pah‑wraiths away.
In the war’s aftermath, the crew of DS9 parts ways, leaving Kira in command of the station as she and Jake gaze toward the wormhole and Sisko’s uncertain return.

EntitySummaries.Benjamin Sisko: Benjamin Sisko fulfills his destiny as Emissary by stopping the Pah‑wraiths and Dukat, sacrificing his linear life to exist with the Prophets.
EntitySummaries.Kira Nerys: Kira Nerys survives the Cardassian assault, says goodbye to Odo, and takes command of DS9, guiding Bajor toward a post‑war future.
EntitySummaries.Odo: Odo ends the Dominion War by curing the Female Changeling and then returns to the Great Link to heal and guide his people.
EntitySummaries.Elim Garak: Elim Garak sees his homeworld devastated but free and chooses to remain on Cardassia to help rebuild from the ruins.
EntitySummaries.Worf: Worf becomes Federation ambassador to Qo’noS, carrying his experiences from DS9 back to the heart of the Klingon Empire.
EntitySummaries.Julian Bashir: Julian Bashir begins a new chapter with Ezri and contemplates a life informed by the ethical compromises he has witnessed.
EntitySummaries.Ezri Dax: Ezri Dax looks ahead with Bashir, having helped her friends through the war and found a place for herself among them.
EntitySummaries.Miles O'Brien: Miles O’Brien prepares to leave DS9 to teach at Starfleet Academy, closing one long chapter of frontier service.
EntitySummaries.Quark: Quark remains on the station, running his bar and insisting that despite all the changes, DS9 will always be good for business.
EntitySummaries.Female Changeling: The Female Changeling surrenders after being cured, agreeing to stand trial and to recall Dominion forces in the Alpha Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.Weyoun: Weyoun’s final clone is killed during the Cardassian assault, ending the line of Vorta who oversaw the Dominion’s occupation.
EntitySummaries.Dukat: Dukat becomes the Pah‑wraiths’ vessel and is ultimately cast into the Fire Caves by Sisko, ending his long vendetta.
EntitySummaries.Kai Winn: Kai Winn attempts a last‑minute redemption by turning on Dukat, but dies in the Fire Caves, her legacy forever tainted.
EntitySummaries.Admiral Ross: Admiral Ross survives the war and shares a quiet toast with Sisko and Martok to honor the fallen.
EntitySummaries.Martok: Martok drinks to victory and loss, leading the Klingons into a new era after the Dominion War.
EntitySummaries.Kasidy Yates: Kasidy Yates grapples with Sisko’s departure to the Prophets while carrying their unborn child and the promise of his eventual return.
EntitySummaries.Jake Sisko: Jake Sisko remains on DS9, looking to the wormhole for signs of his father and continuing his path as a writer.
EntitySummaries.Dominion leadership on Cardassia: Dominion leadership on Cardassia collapses after the surrender, leaving Cardassia shattered but no longer under Founder rule.
EntitySummaries.Pah-wraiths in the Fire Caves: The Pah‑wraiths in the Fire Caves represent an apocalyptic threat that is finally sealed away through Sisko’s sacrifice.

ContinuityNotes: Concludes the Dominion War and the overarching narrative of DS9.
Resolves Sisko’s role as Emissary, Odo’s connection to the Founders, and Cardassia’s fate.
Provides epilogues for all main characters, establishing their post‑war paths.
ThematicNotes: Sacrifice and the question of what legacy one leaves behind.
The possibility of redemption alongside the finality of some choices.
The enduring bonds of found family even as people move on with their lives.
BehindTheScenes: Second half of the DS9 series finale, featuring large‑scale battle footage intercut with intimate farewells.
Uses a montage to show where each main character heads after the war.
Closes out DS9’s darker, serialized take on Star Trek while leaving some elements, like Sisko’s ultimate return, open‑ended.
